title: Will ACLED record any riot/protest events in Senegal during September 2017?
preds: Multiple events most months with the exclusion of August which had only 1 occurrence.
I think one has already happened this month.
Unsure if anything will break out

According to the ACLED data the protest already took place on the 7th of September. [Socialist Women asking for the liberation of Dakar Mayor]
As this is resolved please give us another meaningless question.

Raising my prediction:
Young people on hunger strike since 31st: http://senego.com/greve-de-la-faim-des-jeunes-khalifistes-modou-diagne-fada-considere-que-leur-objectif-est-atteint_556936.html
Concern about how 'militants' will respond to the ministerial reshuffle: http://www.seneweb.com/news/Politique/frustrations-liees-au-remaniement-le-sen_n_226886.html

I think most forecasts are overestimates of the probability based on the base rate.  Although the election caused volatility, it's notable that there have not been any election-related disturbances since July.  So while the base rate and the volatility of the country suggest a riot or protest is likely, I think predictions in the nineties may be too high...

Kemi Saba repatriated to France.  Civil society group THIAT DE Y EN A MARE vows to carry on the anti-government struggle.
http://allafrica.com/stories/201709080698.html
Assuming that inclusion of cases with no fatalities meet the criteria.

There seem to be at least four main reasons for the probability of at least protests this September that may or may not turn into a riot: 1) Senegalâ€™s ruling party (president Macky Sall) emerged victorious during the July elections leaving opponents' issues likely not to be addressed. Plus a new government now needs to be formed. 2) President Macky Sall is expected to proceed with his third cabinet reshuffle with names in the next coming days which will again create tensions with his opponents. 3) Political opponents have still not been released including President Sall's likely presidential opponent, Dakar Mayor Khalifa Sall which caused protests in April this year and will likely to do the same as his trial date is set. It has been reported that authorities have responded quickly to protests so that may be a reason for there being few, if any, protests turning into riots. But even demonstrations intended to be peaceful can turn confrontational and escalate quickly into violence. 4) and the fact that Senegal has had a high number of protests this year with a number of them related to politics.
As others have observed, there have recently been several riots/protests per month.  I'm not aware of any reason why this pattern would stop for Sept 2017.

There have been a small number of events every month for the past year, so it is very likely that there will be events recorded in September. Since the numbers are always  small, the probability is < 100%.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Every month in 2017 saw riots\protests in Senegal, there's no reason to think September will be different

Only not 100 because there has to be some possibility of an extreme outlier. If we're guessing on numbers, Senegal seems about a third less riotous this year than in the proceeding year. 2 protests/riots in September would be my guess.
45 incidents year to date as of August 7, 2017.   That suggests a high probability of an event during September.
Thank you, @rjfmgy, @Dsarin for pointing out that the base rate is 100% likelihood per the ACLED spreadsheet. My face is red for having forecasted 30% at first.

US embassy, in June 2017, released a memo about protests at a university in Dakar https://sn.usembassy.gov/security-message-recurring-protests-dakar-cheikh-anta-diop-university-june-2017/ As the US embassy system in general is not into hair triggers, I assume that until this memo is changed, chances for protests remain high.

According the most recent ACLED database, riot/protest events are common in Senegal.  There were clusters of four riot/protest events recorded in July, six in June and nine in May.  Every month this year has recorded multiple criteria meeting events.  I was unable to find reports of riot/protest events in Senegal this month, but ACLED has yet to publish all of August's data.  I predict at least one riot/protest event in Senegal which will be recorded by ACLED in the month of September.
Between February and July 2017 there were a total of 36 events of type 'Riots/Protests'. All else being equal, the odds of an event occurring in 30 similar days is 99.9%.
Most of the riots/protests appear either attributable or related to the parliamentary elections which concluded in July.
There have been between 4 and 9 every month of 2017 so far
Senegal has more unrest in its foreseeable future.   The basic reasons for the protests continue to exist.
Well there have been multiple riots or protests every month this year so I am certain there will be some sort of riot or protest in September also.
Based on ACLED site data and comments by @rjfmgy and @dsarin .

Well, on the Excel spreadsheet on the ACLED site, at least one riot/protest in Senegal is listed for every month so far in 2017, so I'm going to guess that September will be no different. I confess I really have no idea what this question is actually getting at, and the specific utility of the ACLEC spreadsheet in answering it. The question seems to be essentially, "If an organization identifies a succession of disparate and apparently unrelated events as 'riots/protests,' will it persist in employing that definition for at least one more month?"
